overview.title: Overview
paragraphs: The paper addresses equilibrium logic, a framework extending stable-model and answer-set semantics to the full propositional language, including nested logic programs.
It provides polynomial reductions of primary reasoning tasks associated with equilibrium logic and nested logic programs into quantified propositional logic (QBF).
The tasks include consistency, brave reasoning, skeptical reasoning, and equivalence testing (ordinary, strong, and uniform equivalence).
The paper offers a uniform axiomatization for a variety of problems using a common language, employing QBF solvers as inference engines, and relating equilibrium logic with circumscription.

sections.title: Propositional Language
content: The language consists of logical connectives (¬, ∨, ∧, ⊃), constants (⊤, ⊥), punctuation symbols, and variables.
Formulas are constructed inductively, with logical complexity (lc) defined by occurrences of logical symbols.
Interpretations are sets of variables representing truth assignments.

sections.title: Equilibrium Logic
content: HT-Logic is based on Kripke semantics with two worlds ('here' (H) and 'there' (T)) and a partial ordering H ≤ T.
HT-Interpretations are ordered pairs ⟨I_H, I_T⟩ with I_H ⊆ I_T. Truth values are defined for each world, with specific rules for negation, conjunction, disjunction, and implication.
Models include HT-models and total HT-interpretations ⟨I, I⟩. A formula is HT-satisfiable if it has an HT-interpretation, and HT-valid if all interpretations satisfy it.
Equilibrium Models are minimal total HT-interpretations satisfying specific conditions. These models form the basis of nonmonotonic reasoning in equilibrium logic.
Reasoning Tasks include consistency (existence of equilibrium model), brave reasoning (satisfaction by some equilibrium model), and skeptical reasoning (satisfaction by all equilibrium models).

sections.title: Logic Programs
content: Logic Programs consist of rules with heads and bodies as expressions (formulas without ⊃).
Stable Models are derived by minimizing models of program reducts. Program reducts are obtained by evaluating negations with respect to interpretations.
Examples and Properties illustrate anti-chain properties and equivalences between stable models and equilibrium models.

sections.title: Quantified Propositional Logic
content: The syntax extends classical propositional logic with quantifiers ∀ and ∃. Formulas include bound and free variables, and can be transformed into prenex normal form.
The semantics are based on evaluations using interpretations. QBFs are evaluated using rules for quantifiers and logical connectives.
Properties include relations for shifting and renaming quantifiers, and the formation of formulas in prenex normal form.

sections.title: HT-satisfiability (τ)
content: Translation τ[φ] is inductively defined for atomic formulas, conjunctions, disjunctions, negations, and implications.

sections.title: Here-and-There Logic (THT)
content: Satisfiability in HT is encoded as T_HT[φ] = (V ≤ V') ∧ τ[φ].
The logical complexity of T_HT[φ] is super-linear in the size of the original formula φ.

sections.title: Equilibrium Logic (TE)
content: Equilibrium Model Encoding: T_E[φ] = φ' ∧ ¬∃V ((V < V') ∧ τ[φ]).
The encoding ensures that ⟨I, I⟩ is an equilibrium model if and only if I' satisfies the formula.

sections.title: Logic Programs (TS)
content: Stable Model Encoding uses τ[⋅] on program rules to form τ[Π].
Example: For a program Π = {p ← (q ∧ r) ∨ (¬q ∧ ¬s)}, the reduct and stable model evaluation is demonstrated.
Equilibrium Model Encoding for Programs is derived from T_E[⋅] for logic programs, using transformations that leverage program structure.

sections.title: Consistency
content: Consistency is encoded by ensuring T has an equilibrium model if ∃V' T_E[T] is valid.

sections.title: Brave Reasoning
content: Brave Reasoning is encoded by ensuring T ⊨_b φ if ∃W' (T_E[T] ∧ φ') is valid.

sections.title: Skeptical Reasoning
content: Skeptical Reasoning is encoded by ensuring T ⊨_s φ if ∀W' (T_E[T] → φ') is valid.

sections.title: Reasoning Tasks
content: The primary reasoning tasks in equilibrium logic include:
- Consistency: Checking whether a given theory has an equilibrium model.
- Brave Reasoning: Determining if a given formula is satisfied by at least one equilibrium model of a theory.
- Skeptical Reasoning: Determining if a given formula is satisfied by all equilibrium models of a theory.

sections.title: Complexity Proofs
content: The paper provides detailed proofs for the complexity results, including:
- Membership proofs using the quantifier structure of the translations
- Hardness proofs by reduction from known hard problems
- Proofs for both equilibrium logic and nested logic programs

sections.title: Ordinary Equivalence
content: Two theories are ordinarily equivalent if they have the same equilibrium models.
Formally, theories T1 and T2 are ordinarily equivalent if for any interpretation I, I is an equilibrium model of T1 if and only if it is an equilibrium model of T2.

sections.title: Strong Equivalence
content: Two theories are strongly equivalent if they remain equivalent when added to any other theory.
Formally, theories T1 and T2 are strongly equivalent if for any theory T, the combined theories T1 ∪ T and T2 ∪ T are ordinarily equivalent.

sections.title: Uniform Equivalence
content: Two theories are uniformly equivalent if they are equivalent under all extensions by a set of facts.
Formally, theories T1 and T2 are uniformly equivalent if for any set of facts F, the combined theories T1 ∪ F and T2 ∪ F are ordinarily equivalent.

circumscription.title: Circumscription
paragraphs: Circumscription is a form of nonmonotonic reasoning introduced by McCarthy in 1980. It aims to infer the minimal models of a theory, making assumptions about the world to minimize the extension of some predicates.

In the context of equilibrium logic, circumscription can be related through polynomial reductions. Encodings for equilibrium logic can be shown to correspond to circumscription, extending results for disjunctive logic programs to nested logic programs.
The paper demonstrates the relationship between equilibrium logic and circumscription. It extends Lin's result for disjunctive logic programs to nested logic programs and equilibrium logic.

strong-negation.title: Strong Negation
paragraphs: Strong negation is an extension of classical negation, allowing for the explicit representation of false information.

In equilibrium logic, strong negation can be represented and handled within the same framework, providing a more expressive tool for modeling knowledge and reasoning about incomplete or contradictory information.
The paper discusses the syntactic and semantic integration of strong negation into the logic, as well as its implications for the expressiveness and computational complexity of reasoning tasks.

related-works.title: Related Works
paragraphs: The paper situates its contributions within the broader context of nonmonotonic reasoning and logic programming.
It discusses previous work on stable model semantics, answer set programming, circumscription, and other approaches to nonmonotonic reasoning.
The related works section highlights how the paper's approach differs from or builds upon these earlier efforts, providing a comprehensive review of the state-of-the-art in the field.

concluding-remarks.title: Concluding Remarks
paragraphs: The paper concludes with a summary of the main contributions and findings.
It highlights the significance of polynomial reductions for reasoning tasks in equilibrium logic and nested logic programs.
The concluding remarks also suggest directions for future research, including potential extensions of the framework and applications in various domains of artificial intelligence.

appendix.title: Appendix
paragraphs: The appendix provides additional proofs, examples, and technical details that support the main text.
It includes extended discussions on specific topics, detailed proofs of theorems, and additional examples that illustrate key concepts and results.
Readers are encouraged to refer to the appendix for a deeper understanding of the technical aspects and for supplementary information that complements the main text.
